prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 2mm line survey range 126.93 to 130.57 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Several gas components coexist in the region as the result of the interaction between the violent star-forming phenomena and the environment. Therefore, a wide range of temperatures and densities are found for these gas components. Molecular lines which trace the intermediate temperatures (around 100 K) appear in the 2 mm window. In addition, and due to Orion's physical conditions, the line density is reduced with respect the 1.3 mm window favouring the detection of less abundant species at the proposed frequencies.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The ALMA 2 mm window is still an unexplored domain for Orion-KL. We will use the FDM correlator mode with 937.5 MHz of bandwidth with a velocity resolution of about 1.1 km/s. This spectral resolution has been chosen to sample lines with line-widths ranging from 2 km/s (for emission from the compact ridge, e.g. CH3OCH3) to 30 km/s (for emission from the plateau, e.g. SO2). Our studies based on this source (Table 1) show that most of the line-widths at 2 mm are within this range (see e.g. Tercero et al. 2010, 2013; Esplugues et al. 2013b; Lopez et al. 2014).

Although the spatial structures of most complex organic molecules arise from clumps with sizes below 5 arc-seconds in this domain, some species could show larger scale (15'') emission along the extended ridge component. On the other side, we are interested in resolving the small structures in Orion to derive detailed physical and chemical constrains (see e.g. Favre et al. 2011b [eVLA observations at 0.5'' of spatial resolution] to appreciate the Orion's hot core as a filament containing a chain of small clumps). For this reason we want to improve a factor two the angular resolution of the ALMA SV data (2''). Owing to the large field of view at these frequencies (about 45''), one single pointing is enough to cover the main emission sources.

We consider a continuum flux density of about 1 Jy/beam from the ALMA SV data at 223 GHz (see e.g. Brouillet et al. 2015) although at 2 mm a slightly lower continuum level is expected. A wide range of line flux density (from mJy to 10 Jy) and line widths (from 2 to 30 km/s) are expected in this spectral scan. We have used our previous single dish data to estimate a requested sensitivity of 4 mJy. All lines from abundant species are well above this level. In addition, for the purpose of searching for less abundant species, we can improve the sensitivity level degrading the spatial resolution. We have assumed a linewidth of 5 km/s for the sensitivity calculation due to most of the lines present a spectral feature with v(FWHM) between 2-5 km/s. Only emission arising from the plateau gas component will have wider linewidths.
To the aim of performing a line survey, hence, the highest data rate is needed.

Therefore, a wide range of temperatures and densities are found for these gas components. Molecular lines which trace the intermediate temperatures (around 100 K) appear in the 2 mm window. prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The ALMA 2 mm window is still an unexplored domain for Orion-KL. We will use the FDM correlator mode with 937.5 MHz of bandwidth with a velocity resolution of about 0.9 km/s. This spectral resolution has been chosen to sample lines with line-widths ranging from 2 km/s (for emission from the compact ridge, e.g. CH3OCH3) to 30 km/s (for emission from the plateau, e.g. SO2). Our studies based on this source (Table 1) show that most of the line-widths at 2 mm are within this range (see e.g. Tercero et al. 2010, 2013; Esplugues et al. 2013b; Lopez et al. 2014).

Although some species could show large scale emission along the extended ridge component, the spatial structures of most complex organic molecules arise from clumps with sizes below 7 arc-seconds. Moreover, we are interested in resolving the small structures in Orion to derive detailed physical and chemical constrains (see e.g. Favre et al. 2011b [eVLA observations at 0.5'' of spatial resolution] to appreciate the Orion's hot core as a filament containing a chain of small clumps). For this reason we want to improve a factor two the angular resolution of the ALMA SV data (2''). Owing to the large field of view at these frequencies (17.1''), one single pointing is enough to cover the main emission sources.

Although the spatial structures of most complex organic molecules arise from clumps with sizes below 5 arc-seconds in this domain, some species could show larger scale (15'') emission along the extended ridge component. On the other side, we are interested in resolving the small structures in Orion to derive detailed physical and chemical constrains (see e.g. Favre et al. 2011b [eVLA observations at 0.5'' of spatial resolution] to appreciate the Orion's hot core as a filament containing a chain of small clumps). For this reason we want to improve a factor two the angular resolution of the ALMA SV data (2''). Owing to the large field of view at these frequencies (about 37''), one single pointing is enough to cover the main emission sources.
To the aim of performing a line survey, hence, the highest data rate is needed.

A wide range of line flux density (from mJy to 10 Jy) and line widths (from 2 to 30 km/s) are expected in this spectral scan. In addition, for the purpose of searching for less abundant species, we can improve the sensitivity level degrading the spatial resolution. We have assumed a linewidth of 5 km/s for the sensitivity calculation due to most of the lines present a spectral feature with v(FWHM) between 2-5 km/s. Only emission arising from the plateau gas component will have wider linewidths.
To the aim of performing a line survey, hence, the highest data rate is needed.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 0.9 mm line survey: 275.11-278.84 GHz; 287.11-290.84 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Several gas components coexist in the region as the result of the interaction between the violent star-forming phenomena and the environment. Therefore, a wide range of temperatures and densities are found for these gas components. Molecular lines which trace the high temperatures (200-300 K) appear in the 1-0.8 mm window. Lines from highly vibrational states will be detected in the proposed range.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Some of the ranges within the ALMA 1-0.8 mm window are still unexplored for Orion-KL. We will use the FDM correlator mode with 1.875 GHz of bandwidth with a velocity resolution of about 1.2 km/s. This spectral resolution has been chosen to sample lines with line-widths ranging from 2 km/s (for emission from the compact ridge, e.g. CH3OCH3) to 30 km/s (for emission from the plateau, e.g. SO2). Our studies based on this source (Table 1) show that most of the line-widths at 1 mm are within this range (see e.g. Tercero et al. 2010, 2013; Esplugues et al. 2013b; Lopez et al. 2014).

Although the spatial structures of most complex organic molecules arise from clumps with sizes below 5 arc-seconds in this domain, some species could show larger scale (10'') emission along the extended ridge component. On the other side, we are interested in resolving the small structures in Orion to derive detailed physical and chemical constrains (see e.g. Favre et al. 2011b [eVLA observations at 0.5'' of spatial resolution] to appreciate the Orion's hot core as a filament containing a chain of small clumps). For this reason we want to improve a factor two the angular resolution of the ALMA SV data (2''). As the field of view at these frequencies (20.1'') is smaller than the emitting region, we will performe a 25''x25'' mosaic (7 points). In addition, ACA observations are required to fully characterize abundant species whose emission could come from the most extended regions in Orion.

We have extrapolated the continuum flux density value (3 Jy/beam) from that found in the ALMA SV data at 223 GHz (1 Jy/beam, see e.g. Brouillet et al. 2015) and according to our single-dish observations. A wide range of line flux density (from mJy to 10 Jy) and line widths (from 2 to 30 km/s) are expected in this spectral scan. We have used our previous single dish data to estimate a requested sensitivity of 15 mJy. All lines from abundant species are well above this level. In addition, for the purpose of searching for less abundant species, we can improve the sensitivity level degrading the spatial resolution. We have assumed a linewidth of 5 km/s for the sensitivity calculation due to most of the lines present a spectral feature with v(FWHM) between 2-5 km/s. Only emission arising from the plateau gas component will have wider linewidths.
High data rate is required for the aim of performing a spectral survey. Nevertheless, we have averaged the spectral resolution to reduce the amount of data at these frequencies.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 0.9 mm line survey: 278.81-282.54 GHz; 290.81-294.54 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Several gas components coexist in the region as the result of the interaction between the violent star-forming phenomena and the environment. Therefore, a wide range of temperatures and densities are found for these gas components. Molecular lines which trace the high temperatures (200-300 K) appear in the 1-0.8 mm window. Lines from highly vibrational states will be detected in the proposed range.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Some of the ranges within the ALMA 1-0.8 mm window are still unexplored for Orion-KL. We will use the FDM correlator mode with 1.875 GHz of bandwidth with a velocity resolution of about 1.15 km/s. This spectral resolution has been chosen to sample lines with line-widths ranging from 2 km/s (for emission from the compact ridge, e.g. CH3OCH3) to 30 km/s (for emission from the plateau, e.g. SO2). Our studies based on this source (Table 1) show that most of the line-widths at 1 mm are within this range (see e.g. Tercero et al. 2010, 2013; Esplugues et al. 2013b; Lopez et al. 2014).

Although the spatial structures of most complex organic molecules arise from clumps with sizes below 5 arc-seconds in this domain, some species could show larger scale (10'') emission along the extended ridge component. On the other side, we are interested in resolving the small structures in Orion to derive detailed physical and chemical constrains (see e.g. Favre et al. 2011b [eVLA observations at 0.5'' of spatial resolution] to appreciate the Orion's hot core as a filament containing a chain of small clumps). For this reason we want to improve a factor two the angular resolution of the ALMA SV data (2''). As the field of view at these frequencies (19.8'') is smaller than the emitting region, we will performe a 25''x25'' mosaic (7 points). In addition, ACA observations are required to fully characterize abundant species whose emission could come from the most extended regions in Orion.

We have extrapolated the continuum flux density value (3 Jy/beam) from that found in the ALMA SV data at 223 GHz (1 Jy/beam, see e.g. Brouillet et al. 2015) and according to our single-dish observations. A wide range of line flux density (from mJy to 10 Jy) and line widths (from 2 to 30 km/s) are expected in this spectral scan. We have used our previous single dish data to estimate a requested sensitivity of 15 mJy. All lines from abundant species are well above this level. In addition, for the purpose of searching for less abundant species, we can improve the sensitivity level degrading the spatial resolution. We have assumed a linewidth of 5 km/s for the sensitivity calculation due to most of the lines present a spectral feature with v(FWHM) between 2-5 km/s. Only emission arising from the plateau gas component will have wider linewidths.
High data rate is required for the aim of performing a spectral survey. Nevertheless, we have averaged the spectral resolution to reduce the amount of data at these frequencies.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 0.9 mm line survey: 282.51-286.24 GHz; 294.51-298.24 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Several gas components coexist in the region as the result of the interaction between the violent star-forming phenomena and the environment. Therefore, a wide range of temperatures and densities are found for these gas components. Molecular lines which trace the high temperatures (200-300 K) appear in the 1-0.8 mm window. Lines from highly vibrational states will be detected in the proposed range.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Some of the ranges within the ALMA 1-0.8 mm window are still unexplored for Orion-KL. For this reason we want to improve a factor two the angular resolution of the ALMA SV data (2''). In addition, ACA observations are required to fully characterize abundant species whose emission could come from the most extended regions in Orion.

We have extrapolated the continuum flux density value (3 Jy/beam) from that found in the ALMA SV data at 223 GHz (1 Jy/beam, see e.g. Brouillet et al. 2015) and according to our single-dish observations. A wide range of line flux density (from mJy to 10 Jy) and line widths (from 2 to 30 km/s) are expected in this spectral scan. We have used our previous single dish data to estimate a requested sensitivity of 15 mJy. All lines from abundant species are well above this level. We have assumed a linewidth of 5 km/s for the sensitivity calculation due to most of the lines present a spectral feature with v(FWHM) between 2-5 km/s. High data rate is required for the aim of performing a spectral survey. Nevertheless, we have averaged the spectral resolution to reduce the amount of data at these frequencies.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Orion-KL cloud is the closest high-mass star-forming region in our Galaxy. Due to its chemical complexity this source offers an unique opportunity for the study of the chemistry of the ISM, and for the search of new molecular species in coordination with experimental spectroscopists. We propose to expand the available frequency ranges observed in this source with ALMA with a line survey in Band 4 (126.9-163 GHz) and Band 7 (275.1-328.7 GHz). The main goal is to fully characterize the physical properties of the gas by the analysis of all isotopologues and vibrationally excited states of different families of molecules. In addition, these observations could give us a major opportunity to fully characterize the chemistry by detecting new complex organic molecules. Moreover, it will provide an ALMA legacy spectral survey of Orion. A complete molecular census and a deep characterization of the different species can be only addressed with a selected set of frequency ranges in the millimeter and sub-millimeter domains as proposed here.
